lens.book: The Innovator's Dilemma -- Clayton M. Christensen, Ch 1-4: Why Great Firms Fail

library_composition.note: Design-stack elements derive from host calls (andreas-call.txt) + Kahneman and guest calls (nneka-call.txt) + Kahneman. Previous reverse-benchmark elements derive from Airbnb + Cialdini (Ch 3-4). Current run derives from Airbnb + Christensen (Ch 1-4).

reinforcements.analysis: The Total Monthly Cost Badge is the strongest reinforcement in this run. The design-stack pipeline produced communicates-002 (Single-Sum Financial Display) from inside-out analysis of the Andreas call, where the host thinks in monthly rent and three-month sums. The design-stack guest pipeline produced guest-communicates-002 and guest-feels-002 (Price Surprise Shield) from the Nneka call, where date changes create financial ambiguity. This reverse-benchmark run arrives at the identical prescription -- one total number first, breakdown on demand -- from the completely independent outside-in analysis of Airbnb's nightly-rate mirage. When the inside-out analysis of user needs and the outside-in analysis of competitor failures both converge on the same UI pattern, that is the highest-confidence signal the pipeline can produce.
reinforcements.evidence_triangulation: Design-stack evidence: Andreas processes pricing as monthly sums (andreas-call.txt, 3:02-3:16). Guest evidence: Shomit Ghosh says 'I think of this per month and then break it down per night' (crossref Layer 2). Competitor evidence: Airbnb displays nightly rate, hides fees until checkout, creating 20-40% cost gap. Book evidence: Kahneman's WYSIATI principle (design-stack) and Christensen's value-network metrics mismatch (reverse-benchmark) both explain why the total-first display is structurally correct.
reinforcements.recommendation: This element should be promoted to 'validated' status in the library. The convergence across 5 independent lenses (3 design-stack + 1 previous reverse-benchmark social proof via rb-ui-006 Commitment Reassurance + 1 current reverse-benchmark) makes it the most-validated financial display pattern in the system.

reinforcements.analysis: The Host Identity Card reinforces the design-stack's System 1 Trust Gate (works-001), Human-to-Digital Trust Bridge (works-004), Trust Credential Stack (communicates-003), and Human Thread (feels-008). The design-stack arrived at these elements by analyzing how hosts need to feel the platform is 'the same conversation' they had on the phone (inside-out, host-centric). This reverse-benchmark run arrives at the Host Identity Card by analyzing Airbnb's structural inability to surface person-centric information in its property-centric listing architecture (outside-in, competitor-gap). The convergence: both pipelines independently conclude that System 1 trust formation requires human identity as a first-class visual element. The design-stack says 'the agent's photo should be on the dashboard.' The reverse-benchmark says 'the host's lifestyle should be on the listing.' Same principle, different application surfaces.
reinforcements.evidence_triangulation: Design-stack evidence: works-001 prescribes passing System 1 assessment in under 2 seconds with visual continuity. Competitor evidence: Airbnb listings show property photos, not host personality. Transcript evidence: hemeden-call ('make sure they're not crazy'), louise-call ('if they are drunk... these are realities'), stephanie-call ('opportunity to interview them'). All independently confirm the person-centric trust gap.
reinforcements.recommendation: The Host Identity Card extends the trust-gate principle from the host onboarding journey (where the agent is the trust anchor) to the guest evaluation journey (where the host is the trust anchor). The library should add this as a new element with cross-references to works-001 and feels-008.

reinforcements.analysis: The Weekly Pulse reinforces the design-stack guest pipeline's Stays Manager elements (guest-works-003: System 1 Dashboard, guest-feels-004: Weekly Glance emotional arc). The design-stack arrived at the weekly cadence from analyzing Nneka's pattern of checking the Stays Manager weekly. The reverse-benchmark arrives at weekly check-ins from analyzing Airbnb's complete absence during active stays. The convergence is on the weekly rhythm: both pipelines independently identify 7 days as the natural check-in cadence for mid-term stays. The reverse-benchmark adds the graduated escalation dimension (Great/Fine/Could be better) that the design-stack's Stays Manager elements did not explicitly address.
reinforcements.evidence_triangulation: Design-stack evidence: guest-feels-004 documents the 13-week emotional arc with weekly touchpoints. Competitor evidence: Airbnb sends one check-in at Day 3 and nothing until checkout review. Transcript evidence: tammy-call ('leaves you to your own devices'), tag-call ('headache to deal with').
reinforcements.recommendation: The Weekly Pulse is an extension of the Stays Manager ecosystem. It adds the issue-surfacing mechanism that guest-works-003 and guest-feels-004 assumed but did not specify. Add to library as a new element, cross-referenced to the Stays Manager cluster.

reinforcements.analysis: The Welcome-Back Card reinforces the design-stack's Agent Continuity Frame (communicates-006) and Forward Momentum at Close (feels-006). The design-stack derived these from the phone call analysis: the agent should persist as a visible identity, and every interaction should end looking ahead. The reverse-benchmark derives the Welcome-Back Card from Airbnb's structural amnesia -- the platform forgets relationships between stays. The convergence: both pipelines value persistence of human connection. The design-stack applies it to the agent-host bond; the reverse-benchmark applies it to the host-guest bond. The underlying principle is identical: relationships are assets the platform must preserve, not transactions to be discarded.
reinforcements.evidence_triangulation: Design-stack evidence: feels-006 prescribes forward-looking closes. Competitor evidence: Airbnb has no rebooking tools, actively discourages off-platform contact. Transcript evidence: 5 independent hosts describe preferring 'same person over and over' (nakoley-renville, tag, stephanie, zein, chantel). This is the strongest transcript-validated pattern in the entire corpus.
reinforcements.recommendation: The Welcome-Back Card fills a gap the design-stack explicitly identified but did not resolve. Layer 2 crossref recommended adding a 'Relationship Memory' element. This is that element. Add to library with cross-references to communicates-006 and feels-006.

reinforcements.analysis: The Proposal Ceremony Card reinforces the design-stack's Pre-Packaged Proposal (communicates-005) and Confirm-Not-Construct (behaves-003) patterns, AND the previous reverse-benchmark's Mutual Pledge Card (rb-ui-001). This is a triple convergence across all three process types: (1) Design-stack says proposals should be confirmations, not constructions. (2) Previous reverse-benchmark (Cialdini lens) says the booking moment should feel like a mutual pledge to activate commitment-consistency. (3) Current reverse-benchmark (Christensen lens) says the booking ceremony should match the psychological gravity of a multi-month cohabitation commitment. Three independent analyses, using three different theoretical frameworks, all converge on the same UI pattern: booking as bilateral ceremony, not unilateral transaction.
reinforcements.evidence_triangulation: Design-stack: communicates-005 prescribes present-decisions-as-confirmations. Previous reverse-benchmark: rb-ui-001 (Mutual Pledge Card) prescribes bilateral pledge activation via Cialdini's commitment principle. Current reverse-benchmark: Christensen's Ch 4 explains why Airbnb cannot add deliberation to checkout without degrading vacation conversion. All three arrive at the same destination from different starting points.
reinforcements.recommendation: The Proposal Ceremony Card should be merged with rb-ui-001 (Mutual Pledge Card) into a single, high-confidence element. The Christensen lens adds the structural-moat analysis (why competitors cannot copy) to the Cialdini lens's behavioral mechanism (why the ceremony works psychologically). Combined, they create the most complete specification for the booking moment in the library.

reinforcements.analysis: The Arrival Welcome Kit reinforces the design-stack's Stays Manager as System 1 Dashboard (guest-works-003), the Discovery Promise (guest-feels-006), the Human Thread (feels-008), and the previous reverse-benchmark's Pre-Arrival Conversation Guide (rb-ui-003). The design-stack established that the Stays Manager should be the guest's home base. The previous reverse-benchmark established that pre-arrival communication needs structure. This run adds the arrival-day onboarding sequence that sits between pre-arrival communication and the weekly Stays Manager rhythm. The three pipelines together describe a complete arrival arc: structured pre-arrival conversation (rb-ui-003) -> Day 1 Welcome Kit (elem-006) -> weekly Stays Manager (guest-works-003).
reinforcements.evidence_triangulation: Design-stack: guest-works-003 establishes the Stays Manager as the guest's weekly touchpoint. Previous reverse-benchmark: rb-ui-003 establishes structured pre-arrival conversation. Current reverse-benchmark: Christensen's Ch 3 excavator analogy explains why arrival onboarding 'has never warranted the expense' in the vacation value network. Transcript: chantel-call ('need another night to get acclimated').
reinforcements.recommendation: Add to library. Cross-reference rb-ui-003 as the pre-arrival precursor and guest-works-003 as the post-arrival continuation. Together they form a complete guest onboarding arc.

contradictions.analysis: The Host Identity Card uses a visual language -- 80px circular avatar with 3px purple border, 24px Inter semibold name treatment, lifestyle pill badges -- that introduces a new visual identity system (host-as-brand) within the listing page. The existing library element looks-004 (Agent Identity as Visual Anchor) reserves the circular-avatar-with-name pattern specifically for the Split Lease agent as the persistent trust element across the platform. Placing a similarly styled avatar for the HOST on the listing page could create a visual hierarchy conflict: whose face is the trust anchor? The agent or the host?
contradictions.resolution: This is a productive tension, not a true contradiction. The resolution is contextual: on host-facing screens (dashboard, listing wizard), the agent's identity is the trust anchor. On guest-facing screens (listing detail, search), the host's identity is the trust anchor. The design system should differentiate the two through subtle treatment differences: agent avatars could use a green accent border (per looks-005 Green Trust Badges), while host avatars use the purple accent border. This maintains the visual grammar while serving both trust contexts.

contradictions.analysis: The Host Identity Card is an information-dense component: host photo, name, tagline, 5 lifestyle tags, 3 stats, communication style paragraph, and 4 time-of-day entries in the 'Daily Life Preview'. The existing library element communicates-004 (Seven-Second Unit Description) prescribes matching the phone call's information density, where Andreas described two units in 7 seconds. The Host Identity Card, by contrast, presents roughly 15-20 data points about the host. This exceeds the cognitive load constraints established by communicates-001 (Anchor-Then-Advance: max 3 data points on load, max 15 words in anchor).
contradictions.resolution: The Host Identity Card should follow the library's progressive disclosure pattern (looks-006). On load, show only the anchor: host photo, name, and top 3 lifestyle tags (matching the 3-data-point constraint). The track record stats, communication style, and daily life preview should be in an expanded state triggered by 'See full profile'. This preserves the card's signature value while respecting the cognitive load constraints the design-stack established.

extensions.description: The design-stack's trust gate (works-001), trust bridge (works-004), and trust credential stack (communicates-003) were all designed for the HOST journey -- helping hosts trust the platform. The Host Identity Card extends these same principles to the GUEST journey -- helping guests trust the host. This is a surface extension: same principle (System 1 trust formation through human identity), new application context (guest evaluating host, not host evaluating platform). The library had no guest-facing trust-formation element at the listing evaluation stage.
extensions.validation_note: This extension should be validated against guest call transcripts in a future design-stack run. The reverse-benchmark evidence (competitor gap analysis) is strong, but direct guest testimony about the specific data points that build cohabitation trust (lifestyle tags, daily routine preview, track record stats) would strengthen the element specification.

extensions.description: The design-stack's Stays Manager elements (guest-works-003, guest-feels-004) established the weekly cadence and the emotional arc of a 13-week stay. The Weekly Pulse extends this by adding a structured interaction mechanism: the 3-option response (Great/Fine/Could be better) with graduated issue escalation. The design-stack described what the guest sees on the Stays Manager; the reverse-benchmark describes what the guest DOES on the Stays Manager. This is a mechanism extension: same container (Stays Manager), new interactive behavior (issue surfacing).
extensions.validation_note: The graduated escalation mechanism (surface to host gently vs. private log) should be validated against guest call transcripts. The tone calibration ('we will share this gently, without your exact words') is critical and should be tested with real guest language patterns.

extensions.description: The design-stack's Agent Continuity Frame (communicates-006) and Forward Momentum (feels-006) apply to the onboarding-through-active-lease journey. The Welcome-Back Card extends these to a completely new lifecycle phase: post-stay retention and re-engagement. The library had no elements addressing the period between stays. This is a phase extension: same principles (identity persistence, forward momentum), new lifecycle territory (inter-stay period). The Layer 2 crossref explicitly recommended this extension.
extensions.validation_note: Retention mechanisms should be validated against hosts who have had repeat guests. The transcript evidence is strong (5 hosts independently articulate the desire for recurring guests), but the specific UI of the Welcome-Back Card (availability matching, pre-filled terms, fast-track acceptance) needs usability validation.

extensions.description: The design-stack's proposal elements (communicates-005, behaves-003) are functionally complete: they describe how to present proposals as confirmations rather than constructions. The previous reverse-benchmark's Mutual Pledge Card (rb-ui-001) adds the behavioral mechanism (commitment-consistency activation). The Proposal Ceremony Card extends both by adding the EMOTIONAL dimension: the booking moment should feel ceremonial, not just efficient. Centered layout, generous whitespace, gradient header, side-by-side portraits, 'Your Shared Living Agreement' framing. This is an emotional elevation extension: same functionality, but with deliberate ceremony design that matches the psychological gravity of the commitment.
extensions.validation_note: This extension synthesizes across two independent lenses (Cialdini and Christensen) and the design-stack's functional spec. The emotional elevation is a design interpretation, not a user-stated need, but it is well-grounded in the Christensen analysis of why Airbnb's checkout cannot be modified to serve mid-term commitments.

extensions.description: The previous reverse-benchmark's Pre-Arrival Conversation Guide (rb-ui-003) covers the pre-move-in communication. The design-stack's Stays Manager (guest-works-003) covers the weekly check-in cadence. The Arrival Welcome Kit fills the temporal gap between these two: the Day 1 experience. This creates a complete guest onboarding timeline: pre-arrival conversation (rb-ui-003) -> arrival day welcome (elem-006) -> Week 1 pulse check-in (elem-003) -> ongoing Stays Manager (guest-works-003). This is a temporal bridge extension: it connects two existing elements by filling the gap between them.
extensions.validation_note: The specific content of the Welcome Kit (first 48 hours checklist, neighborhood essentials, host routine reminder) should be validated against guest call transcripts. The content prioritization (what guests actually need on Day 1 vs. what designers assume they need) is a key validation target.

cross_process_insights.title: Total Cost Transparency: The Strongest Signal in the System
cross_process_insights.insight: The total-first financial display is now the most-validated pattern across the entire element library. The design-stack arrived at it from host call analysis (Andreas thinks in monthly sums). The guest design-stack arrived at it from guest call analysis (Shomit thinks in monthly totals). The previous reverse-benchmark contributed Commitment Reassurance (rb-ui-006) which includes pricing clarity at the commitment moment. This run adds the competitive structural analysis: Airbnb cannot show monthly totals because nightly-rate anchoring drives short-stay conversion. Five independent lenses, two process types, one identical conclusion. This is not a design preference -- it is a structural truth about mid-term housing UX.
cross_process_insights.strategic_implication: Ship this first. It requires the least engineering effort, creates the most immediate trust differentiation, and has the highest evidence confidence of any element in the library.

cross_process_insights.title: Person-Centric Architecture: Independent Discovery from Both Directions
cross_process_insights.insight: The design-stack analyzed host calls and concluded: the platform must feel like 'the same conversation' -- human identity (agent photo, name, voice) must be the trust anchor at every screen. The reverse-benchmark analyzed Airbnb's listing architecture and concluded: listings must foreground the person, not just the property, because cohabitation is a human compatibility question. These are the same architectural principle discovered from opposite directions. The design-stack said 'put the human first' based on what users need. The reverse-benchmark said 'put the human first' based on what competitors cannot do. When inside-out need and outside-in opportunity align on the same architectural principle, the platform should treat that principle as foundational, not optional.
cross_process_insights.strategic_implication: The person-centric architecture should be elevated from an element-level pattern to a platform-level principle. It applies across all surfaces: agent identity on host-facing screens, host identity on guest-facing listings, guest identity on host dashboards. The design system tokens should include 'identity treatment' as a first-class category alongside color, typography, and spacing.

cross_process_insights.title: Active Stay Management: The Cost-Structure Moat Explained
cross_process_insights.insight: The design-stack produced detailed Stays Manager specifications (weekly dashboard, date-change tool, emotional arc) from guest need analysis. The reverse-benchmark adds the critical WHY: Christensen's cost structure analysis explains that Airbnb structurally cannot build active stay management because per-booking operational cost has no incremental fee revenue in their value network. The design-stack tells us WHAT to build. The reverse-benchmark tells us WHY competitors will not copy it. Together, they create the complete case for active stay management as Split Lease's deepest structural moat.
cross_process_insights.strategic_implication: Active stay management should be positioned internally as a moat, not just a feature. The Christensen analysis provides the competitive strategy narrative: build this into the cost structure from Day 1, the way minimills embedded low-margin rebar production into their economics. Competitors cannot retrofit it without destroying their unit economics.

cross_process_insights.title: Relationship Continuity: The Retention Layer No Competitor Can Build
cross_process_insights.insight: The design-stack's forward-momentum principle (feels-006: every interaction ends looking ahead) and the previous reverse-benchmark's Post-Review Forward Commitment Bridge (rb-ui-004: leverage post-review consistency pressure) both point toward relationship continuity as the retention mechanism. This run adds the Welcome-Back Card (elem-004) and the Christensen analysis of why Airbnb's fee intermediation model actively opposes relationship continuity. The transcript evidence is overwhelming: 5 hosts independently articulate the value of recurring guests. The combined insight across all three process contributions is: relationship continuity is not a feature category but a business model differentiator. The lease -- not the booking -- must be the unit of value.
cross_process_insights.strategic_implication: The library should add 'Relationship Memory' as a named pattern that connects feels-006, rb-ui-004, and elem-004 into a coherent retention strategy. This is the compounding moat: each successful stay deepens the relationship, making the next booking easier and reducing platform acquisition costs.

cross_process_insights.title: The Proposal Ceremony: Triple Convergence Across Three Theoretical Frameworks
cross_process_insights.insight: This is the only pattern in the library where three independent theoretical frameworks converge on the same UI specification: (1) Kahneman (design-stack): proposals should be confirmations, not constructions, because depleted System 2 cannot construct from scratch. (2) Cialdini (previous reverse-benchmark): the booking moment should activate commitment-consistency through visible mutual pledging. (3) Christensen (current reverse-benchmark): Airbnb's checkout cannot accommodate deliberation because speed-to-book drives vacation conversion. Three frameworks, three process runs, one UI: bilateral ceremony with ceremonial visual treatment. This triple convergence is unique in the library and represents the highest theoretical confidence for any interaction pattern.
cross_process_insights.strategic_implication: Merge elem-005 and rb-ui-001 into a single, definitive Proposal Ceremony element. The combined element has the most diverse theoretical backing of any pattern in the system.

elem-002.notes: Uses --primary-purple, --secondary-purple, --bg-off-white, --border-color consistently. Border-left accent treatment matches the library's visual language. Typography uses Inter for numbers and DM Sans for labels, consistent with tokens. The 12px border-radius aligns with the token system's --rounded-xl.

elem-003.notes: Uses the token system's color variables correctly. Progress bar uses --accent-purple. Response buttons follow the pill-shaped interaction pattern. Issue category chips match the design language of lifestyle tags. 11px DM Sans semibold uppercase for section labels is consistent with the library pattern.

elem-004.notes: Uses the gradient purple accent bar (4px left border) consistently with the library's emphasis treatment. Avatar sizing (48px) is appropriate for secondary context. Returning badge in --secondary-purple maintains the purple trust signal vocabulary.

issues: Uses 'Inter' and 'DM Sans' font families. The library tokens specify 'Instrument Serif', 'Outfit', and 'IBM Plex Mono'. The elem-001 font stack does not reference the library's token fonts at all. This is a visual fragmentation risk.

Uses '--shadow-purple-sm: 0 2px 4px rgba(49,19,93,0.2)' -- a purple-tinted shadow. The library tokens specify shadows with rgba(26,23,20,x) -- a warm neutral shadow. Purple shadows create a different visual feel than the library's warm-neutral shadow system.
The 80px avatar with 3px --secondary-purple border is a new visual pattern not present in the token system. The library does not define avatar sizing or border treatment tokens.
elem-001.remediation: Replace Inter with Outfit (sans) and DM Sans with Outfit for body text. Use Instrument Serif for the 'Meet Your Host' section label. Replace purple shadows with the library's warm-neutral shadow tokens (shadows.sm, shadows.md). Define avatar sizing as a new token category rather than ad hoc pixel values.

issues: Same font stack issue as elem-001: uses Inter and DM Sans instead of the library's Instrument Serif, Outfit, and IBM Plex Mono.
The gradient header (linear-gradient from #31135D to #5a2d8f to #ffffff) introduces a gradient not defined in the token system. The library defines solid colors only.
The ceremonial visual treatment (centered layout, generous whitespace, fade-in animation) is not described by any existing token. This may need a new 'ceremony' token category.
elem-005.remediation: Adopt the library's font stack. The gradient could be defined as a new token (e.g., 'gradient-ceremony') if the ceremony pattern is accepted into the library. The centered ceremonial layout is a layout pattern, not a token violation, and can remain as-is.

issues: Same font stack issue as other elements.
The 120px avatar on the welcome card exceeds any existing sizing token. The library's spacing maxes out at 60px (xxl).
The horizontal swipe-card pattern is a new interaction pattern not described in the library's behavior tokens.
elem-006.remediation: Adopt library font stack. Define a new spacing token for extra-large hero elements (e.g., spacing.hero: 120px). The swipe-card interaction pattern should be added to the library's behavior patterns if the Welcome Kit is accepted.

token_compliance.systemic_issue: All 6 new elements use Inter + DM Sans as their font stack, while the library tokens specify Instrument Serif + Outfit + IBM Plex Mono. This is a systematic divergence introduced by the reverse-benchmark process, likely because the element specifications were designed in isolation from the token system. Remediation: before any element is built, the font stack must be reconciled to the library tokens. This is a single find-and-replace operation that does not affect the elements' functional design.

discovery.coverage_note: Discovery has contributions from all three process types but no new element from this run. The Stay Purpose Selector (rb-ui-005) from the previous run addresses the situation-first discovery that Layer 0 identified as a category blind spot.

search.coverage_note: Search now has strong coverage. The Host Identity Card (elem-001) and Total Monthly Cost Badge (elem-002) fill the two biggest gaps Layer 0 identified: person-centric evaluation and total-cost transparency. rb-ui-002 (People-Like-You Review Filter) addresses the similarity-matched social proof gap.

listing_evaluation.coverage_note: Listing evaluation was a significant gap -- the design-stack focused on host-facing screens while evaluation is guest-facing. This run's Host Identity Card (elem-001) directly fills the largest gap. Combined with rb-ui-002, the listing evaluation phase now has person-centric trust signals and relevant review filtering.

proposal_creation_and_negotiation.coverage_note: The proposal phase has the deepest coverage of any phase in the library: design-stack provides the functional mechanics, rb-ui-001 provides the commitment psychology, rb-ui-006 provides the reassurance signals, and elem-005 provides the ceremonial emotional design. This is the most complete phase specification across all process types.

active_stay.coverage_note: Active stay has extensive design-stack guest coverage (Stays Manager, date-change tools, weekly cadence). This run adds the first reverse-benchmark contributions: elem-003 (Weekly Pulse issue surfacing) and elem-006 (Arrival Welcome Kit). These fill the two gaps the design-stack left open: proactive issue escalation and Day 1 onboarding. The active stay phase is now the most comprehensively covered phase in the library.

retention.coverage_note: Retention was a major gap -- the design-stack covered only the agent-host relationship forward momentum, and rb-ui-004 covered only the post-review commitment bridge. This run adds the first concrete retention mechanism: the Returning Guest Welcome-Back Card (elem-004). However, retention remains the least-covered phase relative to its strategic importance. Future runs should prioritize this phase.

next_run_recommendations.recommendation: Run a design-stack guest lens to validate the Host Identity Card data points
next_run_recommendations.rationale: elem-001 prescribes specific data points (lifestyle tags, daily routine preview, track record stats) based on competitor gap analysis and host transcript evidence. But the question 'what data points do GUESTS actually use to evaluate cohabitation compatibility?' has not been directly answered by guest testimony. A design-stack guest run with a Cialdini or Ariely lens could validate which identity card fields are psychologically active and which are noise.

suggested_lens.guest_call: any guest who evaluated a shared room listing before booking
suggested_lens.book: Predictably Irrational (Dan Ariely) or Influence (Cialdini) Ch 5-6 (Liking + Authority)

next_run_recommendations.recommendation: Run a reverse-benchmark against a non-Airbnb competitor to test pattern universality
next_run_recommendations.rationale: Both reverse-benchmark runs so far have used Airbnb as the competitor. The patterns identified (relationship amnesia, active stay vacuum, nightly rate mirage) may be Airbnb-specific or they may be category-universal. Testing against a structurally different competitor -- Furnished Finder (tenant placement model), SpareRoom (roommate matching model), or HousingAnywhere (mid-term rental platform) -- would reveal whether the gaps are specific to Airbnb's vacation-first architecture or endemic to all shared housing platforms.

suggested_lens.book: Thinking, Fast and Slow Part 3 (Overconfidence) or Nudge (Thaler & Sunstein)

next_run_recommendations.recommendation: Run a design-stack host lens focused on the retention phase
next_run_recommendations.rationale: The coverage map shows retention as the least-covered phase relative to its strategic importance. The reverse-benchmark identified relationship memory as a compounding moat, and 5 host transcripts validate the desire for recurring guests. But the library has no elements describing the host-side retention experience: how does the host's dashboard change when a returning guest is available? How does the host perceive the value of relationship continuity over time? A design-stack run from the host perspective on retention would fill this gap.

suggested_lens.host_call: any host who has had a repeat guest or expressed preference for guest continuity
suggested_lens.book: Kahneman Part 4 (Two Selves, experienced utility, memory) or Cialdini Ch 6 (Scarcity)

next_run_recommendations.recommendation: Reconcile the font stack before any element is built
next_run_recommendations.rationale: All 6 new elements use Inter + DM Sans while the library tokens specify Instrument Serif + Outfit + IBM Plex Mono. This is a systematic divergence that must be resolved before any element moves to implementation. The reconciliation is straightforward (font-family substitution) but must be done deliberately to ensure the ceremonial and identity treatments still work with the library's serif + sans system.
next_run_recommendations.suggested_action: Design review session to apply Instrument Serif, Outfit, and IBM Plex Mono to each element's HTML/CSS and verify visual coherence.

next_run_recommendations.recommendation: Merge elem-005 with rb-ui-001 into a definitive Proposal Ceremony element
next_run_recommendations.rationale: The triple convergence (Kahneman + Cialdini + Christensen) on the proposal ceremony makes this the highest-confidence interaction pattern in the system. The two elements should be merged into a single specification that incorporates the commitment-consistency mechanism (from Cialdini/rb-ui-001), the confirm-not-construct interaction model (from Kahneman/communicates-005), and the emotional ceremony design (from Christensen/elem-005). This merged element would have lens_count: 5, making it the most-validated element in the library.
next_run_recommendations.suggested_action: Library maintenance: merge rb-ui-001 and elem-005, update cross-references, increment lens_count to 5.
